Text.val: This allows you to edit the raw XML, to induce changes and errors for testiong.

Text.valUnicode: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fnil\fcharset0 Microsoft Sans Serif;}{\f1\fmodern\fprq1\fcharset0 Courier New;}} {\colortbl ;\red0\green0\blue0;\red255\green0\blue128;} {\*\generator Msftedit 5.41.15.1515;}\viewkind4\uc1\pard\sa195\cf1\b\f0\fs20 One of the XML element types is a type called "Mixed Content". In this type, free text can be mixed with XML tags. This might be used to create form letters, for instance. An example of such data might be:\par \cf2\f1 <CustLetter>\cf1\par Dear Mr.\cf2 <Name>\cf1 John Smith\cf2 </Name>\cf1 .\par Your account \cf2 <CustID>\cf1 1032\cf2 </CustID>\cf1\par is past due since \cf2 <DueDate>\cf1 2001-07-13\cf2 </DueDate>\cf1 .\par \cf2 </CustLetter>\cf1\f0\par This raises the question: how to parse this data? \par Fortunately Magic makes it easy. A "mixed =true" element may be read using an XML view directly.\par Also, there are functions, \cf2 DbMixedGet()\cf1 and \cf2 DbXMLMixedSet()\cf1 , which can be used.\par This example shows how to use both methods.\par \par }

ExpSyntax.val: 'XM18: How Do I Handle Mixed-Content in an XML Document?'

Text.val: Part of the function is initialized here, to make it easier to format.
The DbXMLMixedGet function requires that the XML occurrance be known. In this
example it is accomplished by adding the LSeq line to the data, which holds the position of
this CustLetter in the Letters XML file.

Text.valUnicode: <CustID>1111</CustID> is overdue. The balance was due on
<DueDate>2001-01-01</DueDate>. Thank you for your attention to this matter.
<CustID>2222</CustID> is overdue. The balance was due on
<DueDate>2001-02-02</DueDate>. Thank you for your attention to this matter.
<CustID>3333</CustID> is overdue. The balance was due on
<DueDate>2001-03-03</DueDate>. Thank you for your attention to this matter.
